huntYears.NOTES: This is a Limited-entry hunt that takes place on a General-season unit. You will lose your bonus points if you draw out for this hunt.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This is a pre-rut/early rut hunt that highly depends on weather factors. If weather conditions are warm and/or there hasn't yet been a substantial snow storm bucks may be found solitary or in bachelor groups still at high elevations. Snow and cool temperatures may initiate deer migration to lower elevations as well as early rut behavior with bucks being found grouped up with does in transitional mountain brush habitats or winter range. Be flexible in hunting strategies for greatest chance of success.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, snow, and cold. Early winter storms can create muddy or snowy roads and trails.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 72.2~14000~13500~15–17~16.5~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
General Considerations: This is a very productive unit with both road access to high elevations and backcountry hunting opportunities. If the weather has been mild throughout October then most hunters will find most success hunting on summer habitats at 7,500 feet and above. If there has been a few snowstorms then deer will often begin their fall migration and hunters find success on sagebrush and mid-mountain brush type habitats.

Migration Patterns: Fall migration is very weather dependent on this unit. Most migration occurs in late November when significant snowfall typically occurs. However, big snowstorms in late October have prompted migration during the any weapon hunt. When migration begins (typically in mid October to mid-December) deer move down in elevation to benches on both the east and west sides of the mountain.

Mule Deer rut: The mule deer rut usually runs from mid Nov.-mid Dec. but pre-rut and early rut behaviors may be observed during this hunt.

Recommended areas to hunt: Nebo Loop, Loafer Mtn, Spencer Fork, and Mona and Santaquin Benches on the north Nebo, Chicken Creek, Log Hollow, Red Ledges, and Sage Flats on the Sanpitch Mtns are good places to start looking.

Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential for scouting deer. Find a high vantage point and glass a lot of terrain. If you find does with no bucks grouped up with them, keep checking on the area periodically as bucks will begin to group up with does more and more as the hunt goes on.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_PROVISIONS: This is a Limited-entry hunt that takes place on a General-season unit. You will lose your bonus points if you draw out for this hunt.
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public and Private, Check official map for information.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: All Wildlife Management Areas are open for this hunt except for the "Private Lands Only Hunt" for antlerless elk.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Many improved and primitive camping opportunities on the unit.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The best access points are off the Nebo Loop Road. Forest Service gates are typically locked beginning in November until late April/early May. However there are many secondary canyon roads that offer access to good hunting. See following link to check seasonal road closures. <a href="https://www.fs.usda.gov/main/uwcnf/maps-pubs" target="_blank">https://www.fs.usda.gov/main/uwcnf/maps-pubs.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: Landowners may or may not allow ATV access.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Temporary area and trail closures have been put in place by the Forest Service due to fire mitigation on the northern half of the unit. Please click here for more info or call the Spanish Fork Ranger District Office at 801-798-3571. Please Please be mindful of Wilderness Areas and associated regulations.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Juab, Millard, Sanpete, Sevier and Utah counties—Boundary begins at US-6 and I-15 at Spanish Fork; southeast on US-6 to US-89 near Thistle; south on US-89 to US-50 at Salina; northwest on US-50 to I-15 at Scipio; north on I-15 to US-6 at Spanish Fork. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Maps: Delta, Manti, Nephi, Provo, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Springville office, 801-491-5678.
